text: Tap @ Wrecking Bar Brewpub, Atlanta. Black with next to no head. Has a very stated roasted malt aroma and taste.
Draft - Super thick on the palate. Really gets things coated. Hints of coffee and chocolate. Not as smooth as I was hop no for this evening. Does have a little bite to it.

Poured from the tap into a pint glass at the Battery in Smyrna, Georgia. The appearance is pitch black with a medium sized white head. The aroma is full of roasted malts with some cocoa. The taste is also big on roasted malt with some sweet cocoa. An excellent beer.

Tap at Wrecking Brewpub, Atlanta. Colour is clear dark brown with small slightly brownish head. Aromas and flavors: Chocolate, some dark chocolate, some coffee, dryness, hops and roasted malts. Very good American style hoppy stout.

4/3/16. On tap at the brewpub. Awesome place! Black pour under a nice tan head. Nice aroma, roasted malts, dark chocolate, coffee, some dark fruits. Good flavor, chocolate, some ashiness, coffee. Tasty stuff!
Roast and some caramel. Light chocolate and nut. Black pour with good head and lacing. Great balance. Thick, creamy consistency. Tap at brewpub.

On tap @ Wrecking Bar. Black in color with a tan head. Starts out a touch ashy, but there is a really solid coffee, roast, and molasses quality to it. Sort of a toffee sweetness, hints of dark fruit, and plenty of chocolate. Good bitterness to balance out what is actually pretty moderate sweetness. Very easy drinking.
Awesome stout, chocolate caramel sambuca notes, thick full bodied black with tan head.

On tap at the brewpub. Dark brown pour with a tan head. Smooth with dark roasted malts, bitter chocolate, and caramel highlights. A bit thin in the body, but a really complex and tasty stout. Bravo.....

Come on, peeps, its a quality beer with solid elements. Its generally available at the Wrecking Bar, in fact, it seems to be a permanent fixture to the beer menu these days, but is always a welcome option.

On tap at the brewpub. Pours a deep brown with some copper highlights and a medium sized tan head. Sweet roast and cocoa on the nose, toffee, hints of coffee. Medium bodied, slightly warming alcohol peeking through. Roast and sweet cocoa. Gentle bakers cocoa bitterness on the finish, with a touch of vanilla.
Holy fuck. This is amazing. Balanced and flat out bad ass. All the components youd want in a big stout. Roast, dark fruit, coffee, chocolate. Smooth and bold. Wow.
A very wonderful low gravity beer. Nice bitterness with toasted chocolate flavors and chocolate aroma. Buttery mouthfeel. Light coffee flavors to. A really amazing Stout.

Draft. Brown-black body with small tan head. Aroma is medium sweet, earthy, roast/coffee, some bittersweet chocolate, light grapefruit. Taste is moderately sweet, earthy, chococaramel, some grapefruit, coffee/roast. Medium body, low carbonation, some stickiness.

Draft - Sweet chocolate, coffee and toffee. Jet black with a decent brown head. Toffee, sweet burnt sugars, booze and finishes with burnt toast. This doesnt sound good, but it actually is. Very big, small pours only.
Dont usually drink many stouts--but this is the best tasting Ive ever had....so far
Had this as part of sampler. Perfect for style, with a little smoke, lots of roast and some bite. Dark cola, tan head, and not thin
Draught at Wrecking Bar. Chocolate and roast and all the expected flavors. Nice coffee aroma. Medium body. Nice.
Dark brown with khaki head. Roasted malts and coffee in the nose. Tasted smoky with some chocolate and charred oak. Chewy and hearty. Pretty nice stout.

On tap at the brewpub. Shiny dark brown pour. Mild nose of roasted malts, soil, plum. Flavor is fairly earthy with moderate dark chocolate and coffee notes. Surprisingly hoppy but restrained enough that it works. quite robust.
Very dark brown body w/ khaki head. Roasted, smoky malt nose. Coffee, oak, earthy flavors that end bitter & clean. Hearty stout.
Tap from Lazy Dog. Pours dark opaque brown with toffee colored head. Aroma of intense coffee and chocolate. Taste very similar to the aroma, but the roastiness shines more on the taste.

Draft at the brewery with Linh, Scarlett and mom. Pours a deep black body with thick beige lacing. Aroma is super rich chocolate roast. Mouthfeel is medium to thin with notes of espresso, rich chocolate roast and syrup. Light hop character muddled down low with some dark fruits. Good.
4 oz sample pours a dark black color with a nice off white head.  Aromas of chocolate, dark roasted malt, chocolate.  Medium bodied, with a nice bitter finish.  Good beer
Draft sampling.  Pours dark black with thinner tan creamy beige head.  Smell is roasted malts, hints of coffee and chocolate. Taste is big robust roast, coffee, dark cocoa, light bitter.  Quite nice.

On tap in a flight at the Brewpub. Pours black with a faint ruby tint. Very good lacing. The nose is molasses, coffee, and cardamom. Sweet, with a good roasted spiciness through the finish.  Heavy body, fairly astringent, and warming. Overall, this is a good, flavorful stout. Not too roasted, and smooth. The aftertaste is mostly alcohol warming.

On tap at brewpub. Pours near black with dark tan head. Aromas of roasted malts, chocolate, light coffee, and some hops. Flavors of roasted malts, cocoa, coffee, and finishes with nice amount of hop bitterness. Has nice roasted dryness to it. Pretty tasty stout.

Tap. Pours opaque black with a medium creamy brown head that leaves nice lacing on the glass. Aroma is coffee, dark roasted malts, cigarettes. Flavor is the same, lightly sweet, lightly bitter. Medium body, creamy mouthfeel. Pretty nice.

From tap at the brewpub. Pours dark brown to black with a small tan to brown head. Aroma is roasted malty and breadish. Thick malty, breadish and liqourice. Lingering dark roasted, chocolate and malty.

Draft at brewpub. Black pour with a thick brown head. Bittersweet chocolate candy bars, roasted malts, fresh pressed coffee and creaminess. Big flavor of chocolate milk, milk duds, coffee and roasted malts. Moderate carbonation and a medium sessionable body. Great beer.

Brewvival Trip Beer 49. Draft at the brewpub. Pours a dark brown color with a large creamy tan head. Good head retention. Aroma of roasted malts, bitter chocolate ,coffee, nuts, honey. The taste is roasted malts, coffee,, chocolate, bitter hops, mildly sweet finish. Medium bodied.
Draft at the source. Almost black, brown head. Aroma of sweet dark milk chocolate. Taste is bitter hersheys and espresso. Tasty for a six percenter.

Black pour with tan head and lace. Chocolate malt and a sour light coffee aroma. Sweet coffee start that fades to a sour malt like bitter. Medium bodied with lightly aggressive carbonation, a tad thin and watery on the back end.
On tap at Wrecking Bar.  Nose has a nice mixture of chocolate and roast.  Some bread and caramel behind.  Touch of hop bitterness and slightly dry.
Black color with tan foam. Rich semi-sweet cocoa, coffee, deep roast aromas. medium body. Smooth semi-sweet chocolate flavors with dark roast malts, coffee--very tasty.
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: On tap at the brewpub. Pours black with a creamy dark brown head that dissipates to the edged and laces. Aroma has a nice rich roasted malt note that is backed by dark chocolate and a hint of bitterness. Flavor begins full of roasted malts with a bit of backing dark chocolate and is joined by a hint of bitter coffee in the finish. Smooth.

Draft.  Poured black with a thin tan head.  Aroma was heavily roasted malt, hints of chocolate, some floral hops.  Flavor was roasted malt,  some coffee and chocolate, a hint of vanilla.  Moderately sweet and bitter.  Slightly creamy mouthfeel.
Draft at W.B. Black pour with an off white head. Scent is bready, chocolate, vanilla and roast. Taste is chocolate, coffee and roasted malts. Nice

Black in color with thin tan lacing. A nice roated nose with coffee presence that continues its way onto the palate. Lingering finish and not too heavy but definitely a better beer in cooler weather.

UPDATED: DEC 31, 2012 
Name: Jemmy
Date: June 19, 2011
Mode: Draft
Source: Brewpub
Appearance: black, frothy tan head, icy lace
Aroma: big roasted malt aroma, dark chocolate, coffee
Flavor: rich roasted flavor, lots of coffee character, dark chocolate bitterness
Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 15/20
Rating: 3.6/5.0Drinkability: 8/10
Score: *** /4

Pours black with medium beige head.

Aroma is moderately roasty with a bit of chocolate and coffee qualities coming through.  Much the same in the flavors, with a bit of earthy and floral hop characters.  Maybe dial back the bittering IBUs a few points, but not bad.

Mouthfeel is a little creamy and not overpowered by the roastiness.  Overall, a very nice American stout.

First foray with the new atlanta brew pub and a heck of an experience it was. Solid line up of beers to appeal to a wide variety of tastes and the couple I had were well made and unique enough to keep you entertained. This stout here is no slouch. Nice black pour with a bit of a tan head to add some creaminess. A nice amount of roasty chocolate malt and a pleasant bitterness on the back end. A little sticky sweet that lasts with you for some time. Easily drinkable. Easily accessible. This place is going to do well.

Comes out of the tap an opaque warm sable with a fine-bubbled tan head that leave some substantial lacing. Smoky, chocolaty aroma has a tone of quality coffee and hints of caramel and licorice. Rich flavor has tones of unsweet chocolate, premium roast coffee and caramel, along with hints of licorice, toffee and molasses and just a whisper of hops. Fizzy, lively texture leaves a nice smoky tingle. If you live in Atlanta, or if ever you visit, this one is a must!
Very rich malt. Very slight ash. There are hops there, but theyre hard to pick out with all the roast.

UPDATED: JUL 26, 2011 16 ounce pint - $5.50 at the Wrecking Bar Brewpub in Atlanta, Georgia.

Appearance: Delivered to my corner seat at the bar a near-black body with a bubbly, blotched head displaying a medium sandy-toned hue. Very thin smattering of lace on the way down.

Smell: Noted notes of chocolate and toasted loaf bread, a splash of chilled coffee, a singular drop of vanilla, and a very minute background hint of fruity citrus.

Taste: Sweet-tasting chocolate mixed with sugar-sweetened coffee and layered over lightly toasted bread. Faint hint of licorice. Some dark fruitiness lingering within. Modestly bitter, with the hops yielding a bit of candied lemon. Drying and with a bit more citrus and chocolate on the smooth finish.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. Medium carbonation.

Overall: Its good, its tasty, and plenty flavorful without needing to stoop to the tawdry lows of cheap tricks and base gimmickry.

Update (7/26/11): Seems the second batch has upped the citrus character and hop bitterness, which I didnt care for as much.
